key_insight: What looks like a reasoning failure on abstract-reasoning benchmarks (ARC, ARC-AGI) is largely caused by a perception bottleneck: noisy/ambiguous visual encoding, not core reasoning, explains much of the gap between humans and vision–language models.
problem_solved: Clarifies whether low performance on abstract visual reasoning benchmarks reflects deficits in reasoning or in front-end perception/representation, and provides empirical evidence that perception is the primary limiter.
method: Separate perception from reasoning by comparing model performance on raw images versus idealized / oracle symbolic representations.
Run controlled ablations and diagnostics on VLMs (e.g., replace visual encoder with perfect/cleaned masks or structured tokens) to measure the effect of perceptual noise.
Evaluate across ARC and ARC-AGI tasks to quantify how much performance improves when perception errors are removed or reduced.
impact: Helps researchers and practitioners avoid misattributing failures to reasoning, guiding efforts toward better perceptual front-ends, dataset design, and more diagnostic benchmarks that disentangle perception from reasoning.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram showing 'Image → Perception (encoder) → Representation → Reasoning module' with the perception stage highlighted as the bottleneck.
Bar chart comparing model accuracy on tasks with raw images vs oracle/cleaned representations (large jump when perception is fixed).
Ablation matrix heatmap showing performance changes when progressively improving or degrading perception components.
Example ARC task panels: original image, cleaned oracle representation, and the model's outputs to visually illustrate perception errors vs reasoning steps.
paper_title: Your Reasoning Benchmark May Not Test Reasoning: Revealing Perception Bottleneck in Abstract Reasoning Benchmarks
paper_authors: Xinhe Wang, Jin Huang, Xingjian Zhang, Tianhao Wang, Jiaqi W. Ma
